population_specificity: Male participants aged 18-70 with chronic spinal cord injury and denervation of both knee extensor muscles.
effective_dosage: Training sessions twice weekly (specific LPWS parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and dosimetry of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) with kiloHertz currents (kHz) on aspects of muscle function (AOMF) such as torque and hypertrophy in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The review found that kHz NMES can increase torque and generate hypertrophy, with Russian current studies specifically showing hypertrophy gains. However, dosimetry details were often lacking, making optimal parameter determination difficult.
population_specificity: Healthy people

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) with isokinetic muscle strength (IMS) training improves muscle strength, flexibility, joint ROM, functional status, and quality of life in overweight/obese women with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that combining NMES with IMS significantly improved concentric strength at 240°/s, physical performance, muscle flexibility, and quality of life compared to standard rehabilitation. However, no significant improvements were observed in muscle strength at 60°/s, force asymmetry, or joint ROM.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Two sessions per week (specific NMES parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of non-invasive foot NMES on lower leg symptoms in an elderly, ambulant, and otherwise healthy population.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of NMES, as it appears to describe the study design rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly, ambulant, and otherwise apparently healthy individuals with lower leg symptoms (aches, pain, cramps).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of sensory and motor-level neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in treating post-stroke dysphagia.
results_summary: Sensory-level NMES showed significant improvement in swallow function (FAM, DOSS, NOMS), while motor-level NMES did not. Combined NMES groups improved significantly on most measures, but no significant difference was found between sensory and motor groups.
population_specificity: Thirty-one stroke survivors with dysphagia within 6 months of stroke onset, excluding those with contraindications for electrical stimulation or pre-existing conditions.
effective_dosage: 45 minutes per session, 10 sessions total (sensory or motor intensity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in functional connectivity within a cortical network induced by contralaterally controlled neuromuscular electrical stimulation (CCNMES) versus traditional neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) during wrist extension in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that CCNMES was associated with distinct changes in functional connectivity compared to NMES, suggesting potential differences in cortical activation patterns between the two therapies. However, the abstract does not specify the magnitude or clinical significance of these differences.
population_specificity: Thirty-one stroke patients with right hemisphere lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hemodynamic effects of TENS, NMES, and sham stimulation on venous flow in healthy young individuals.
results_summary: NMES significantly increased flow volume and peak velocity in the popliteal vein, though less than TENS. NMES was less tolerated than TENS but without statistically significant discomfort differences.
population_specificity: 24 healthy university students (50% male).
effective_dosage: Not specified (5 Hz-TENS and NMES applied to soleus muscle).
study_duration: Not specified (single session per stimulation type).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistance exercise alone versus resistance exercise combined with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on muscle strength and mobility in hematological cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that resistance exercise improved muscle weakness in hematological cancer patients, and combining NMES with resistance exercise yielded comparable significant results to resistance exercise alone in patients with moderate-low ECOG-PS.
population_specificity: Adult hematological cancer patients receiving intensive chemotherapy after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of exercise training plus neuromuscular electrical stimulation versus exercise training alone on shoulder function, pain, range of motion, and muscle strength in patients with subacromial impingement syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that adding neuromuscular electrical stimulation to exercise training did not improve shoulder function (primary outcome) more than exercise alone but did enhance muscle strength, external-rotation range of motion, and reduced pain during activity and at night (secondary outcomes). Effect sizes were medium to large for both groups.
population_specificity: Patients with subacromial impingement syndrome (n=48, divided into two groups of 24 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combining NMES of the calf and quadriceps on individuals with knee osteoarthritis (KOA) to manage symptoms.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. The primary outcome will be the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Arthritis Index pain domain at 8 weeks, with secondary outcomes including muscle strength, quality of life, and other measures.
population_specificity: 193 individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Footplate stimulation daily for 30 min and quadriceps stimulation for 20 min, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy of mobile app-based neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in reducing pain for patients with knee osteoarthritis over an additional 14-week period following a 12-week trial.
results_summary: In the per-protocol compliant population, active NMES showed significantly greater pain reduction (64.7% vs. 24.3%) and higher rates of ≥50% pain improvement (76.2% vs. 12.5%) compared to sham NMES. No marked differences were observed in the intent-to-treat population.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis who completed a prior 12-week NMES trial.
effective_dosage: Two 20-minute daily sessions, 5 days per week.
study_duration: 14 weeks (extension study; total 26 weeks including parent study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of traditional dysphagia therapy (TDT) alone versus TDT combined with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on swallowing functionality and related outcomes in post-stroke dysphagia patients.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant post-intervention improvements, but the NMES group demonstrated additional benefits in reducing leakage and penetration-aspiration levels with semi-solid food. Improvements were maintained at the 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Thirty-four patients with post-stroke dysphagia (PSD).
effective_dosage: Sensory NMES was applied for 45 minutes per session, 5 days a week for 3 weeks.
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of NMES in preventing muscle atrophy in ICU patients without nerve injury, specifically evaluating different muscle stimulation approaches.
results_summary: NMES combined with early exercise training reduced muscle atrophy in ICU patients, with simultaneous agonist/antagonist muscle stimulation (Exp I) showing better results than single-muscle stimulation (Exp II). No significant differences were observed in prothrombin time, lactic acid, or C-reactive protein levels across groups.
population_specificity: ICU patients without central or peripheral nerve injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on exercise capacity, dyspnea, quality of life, and physical activity in people with COPD.
results_summary: The study found it uncertain whether NMES has an effect on exercise capacity, dyspnea, quality of life, and physical activity in COPD patients, based on the analyzed systematic reviews.
population_specificity: People with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of long-duration neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on shoulder subluxation and upper-extremity function in acute post-stroke patients.
results_summary: NMES significantly reduced shoulder subluxation and improved upper-extremity function (FMA-UE, FMA-hand and finger subscales) compared to sham treatment, with benefits sustained at follow-up. Functional Independence Measure (FIM) also improved more in the NMES group, but no change in pain levels was observed in either group.
population_specificity: Acute post-stroke patients (mean age 70.0 ± 14.0 years).
effective_dosage: NMES applied to supraspinatus and posterior deltoid muscles (specific parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chronic NMES+ training on muscle strength and mass compared to conventional volitional training or passive electrical stimulation alone.
results_summary: The majority of studies reported increased muscle strength with NMES+, particularly when superimposed on sub-maximal exercises involving concentric and eccentric contractions. Muscle mass results were mixed, with two studies showing increases and two showing no differences.
population_specificity: Healthy participants or orthopedic patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) with plyometric and strength training enhances muscular, sprint, and functional performances in collegiate male football players compared to sham NMES.
results_summary: The study found that both NMES and sham NMES combined with plyometric and strength training improved performance, but NMES showed a greater advantage in enhancing muscular and sprint performance among the participants.
population_specificity: Collegiate male football players (n=60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate recent studies on the effectiveness of transcutaneous NMES applied to the anterior neck as a treatment for dysphagia, considering variations in stimulation protocols, electrode placement, and patient conditions.
results_summary: The review identified 18 studies, with 16 reporting beneficial outcomes for NMES, particularly when combined with traditional dysphagia therapy (TDT) in stroke, Parkinson's disease, and brain injury patients. However, further research is needed to determine optimal protocols and settings for different patient groups and impairment levels.
population_specificity: Patients with dysphagia, including post-stroke, Parkinson's disease, and brain injury cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NMES of the deltoid could lead to early restoration of shoulder function after reverse total shoulder arthroplasty (RSA).
results_summary: NMES contributed to significantly faster restoration of range of motion (ROM) and improvement in external rotation power at 3 and 6 months postoperatively, but no significant differences were found in pain scores (VAS), ASES, or Constant scores, or in deltoid thickness measurements.
population_specificity: 88 patients who underwent RSA for cuff tear arthropathy or irreparable rotator cuff tear.
effective_dosage: NMES was applied to the middle and posterior deltoid area, maintained for 1 month postoperatively (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two NMES protocols on multifidus muscle morphology and function in individuals with non-specific chronic low back pain (CLBP) and assess their impact on pain and disability.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be ongoing or not yet completed.
population_specificity: 30 participants aged 18-60 with non-specific CLBP, recruited from local orthopedic clinics and databases.
effective_dosage: 20 supervised electrotherapy treatments over 10 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on upper limb function, muscle strength, and spasticity in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation combined with other therapies significantly improved functional scale scores, muscle strength, and spasticity in the upper limbs but did not enhance wrist range of motion. The functional benefits persisted at a 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of high-frequency rTMS and TNES in improving dysphagia in acute post-stroke patients.
results_summary: TNES significantly improved swallowing disturbance (SDQ), pharyngeal residue (YPRSRS), and penetration/aspiration severity (PAS) compared to controls, though rTMS was more effective for SDQ and PAS. Both interventions showed comparable efficacy for YPRSRS.
population_specificity: Right-handed acute ischemic stroke patients with post-stroke dysphagia (mean age 60.53 ± 8.23 years).
study_duration: Intervention administered between the 2nd and 10th days post-stroke.

study_goal: To determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation of calf muscles could improve nocturnal symptoms and quality of life in asthmatic children.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation significantly improved nocturnal symptoms, quality of life, and other measured variables compared to breathing exercises alone, with results comparable to aerobic exercise. The intervention showed statistically significant benefits over the control group in all outcomes.
population_specificity: 60 children (8-12 years) with moderate asthma.
effective_dosage: Five days a week for 30 minutes, alongside supervised breathing exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation (CCFES) with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in improving upper extremity motor recovery after stroke.
results_summary: CCFES showed greater improvements than NMES in upper extremity function (measured by UEFMA, BBT, AROM, and mBI), but no significant difference was found for AMAT. The meta-analysis included six RCTs with 267 participants.
population_specificity: People with upper extremity hemiplegia after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a new neuromuscular electrical stimulation system (Helping Hand) could improve motor, sensory, and body representation recovery in chronic stroke patients compared to conventional treatment and a robotic glove.
results_summary: The Helping Hand (HH) system provided earlier motor benefits than the robotic glove (GR) and showed higher overall improvement in motor and somatosensory functions, which persisted at follow-up. HH also improved perceived limb dimensions and reduced altered feelings toward the affected limb, with benefits correlating with motor improvements and dependent on HH dosage.
population_specificity: Sixty chronic stroke patients with unilateral motor deficits.
effective_dosage: Not specified (groups received dose-matched interventions, with GRHH receiving 50% GR and 50% HH).
study_duration: 9 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at week 13.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the efficacy of contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation (CCFES) for post-stroke upper limb rehabilitation compared to cyclic neuromuscular electrical stimulation (cNMES) and task-oriented training (TOT).
results_summary: The study builds on prior pilot and single-site studies showing positive effects of CCFES on upper limb impairment and hand dexterity in stroke survivors, but results from this multi-site trial are pending. The primary endpoint is change in dexterity from baseline to 6 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with moderate to severe upper extremity hemiparesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining repetitive facilitative exercise (RFE) with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improves upper limb function in stroke patients with severe paresis.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of RFE and NMES significantly improved Fugl-Meyer Assessment scores for wrist and finger function compared to conventional training alone, suggesting enhanced distal limb recovery in severe stroke patients.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with very severe upper limb paresis (Finger-Function test scores of zero or 1a on the Stroke Impairment Assessment Set).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of group-specific training (NMES, RFE, RFE under NMES, or conventional training) plus 40 minutes of conventional exercise daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare intervention modalities, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES), for increasing skeletal muscle mass in paralyzed limbs of individuals with chronic, motor complete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: NMES-based resistance training on the quadriceps produced the largest and most consistent increases in skeletal muscle mass among all interventions reviewed. However, the overall studies demonstrated a high risk of bias, and more high-quality trials are needed to optimize training variables.
population_specificity: Adults (>18 years) with chronic (>1-year post-injury), motor complete spinal cord injury.

study_goal: To determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improves mobility in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: NMES improved walking speed and the standing, walking, running, and jumping dimension of the Gross Motor Function Measure compared to conventional physical therapy. The study concluded that NMES is safe and effective for improving mobility in this population.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether simultaneous NMES on quadriceps and gluteal muscles (QG) compared to quadriceps alone (Q) affects knee extensor force production and discomfort.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in knee extensor force production or discomfort between QG-NMES and Q-NMES, with both methods producing comparable results at maximum tolerated intensity and 20% of MVC.
population_specificity: 11 healthy participants (6 females), aged 19-54 years, with normal weight.
effective_dosage: NMES-intensity increased stepwise until maximal tolerable level was reached; specific mA values not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding early neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) to an early mobilization (EM) protocol improves functional outcomes in mechanically ventilated ICU patients.
results_summary: The EM+NMES group showed significantly better functional status scores, shorter hospital stays, fewer days to stand up, lower ICU-acquired weakness, and improved muscle strength compared to the EM-only group.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated patients within the first 48 hours of ICU admission.
effective_dosage: NMES was administered for 60 minutes, 5 days a week.
study_duration: From the first 48 hours of ICU admission until ICU discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of sEMG assessments, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES), in neurorehabilitation after spinal cord injury (SCI) and evaluate its clinical relevance.
results_summary: The review found that NMES was among the interventions studied using sEMG to assess muscle activation and rehabilitation effects, but it highlighted the need for further research on long-term reliability and physiological interpretation of sEMG data.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) undergoing neurorehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) for treating oropharyngeal dysphagia in children.
results_summary: Swallowing function improved after NMES treatment in all included studies, with some evidence of improved feeding ability, though the studies had moderate to high risk of bias and short follow-up durations.
population_specificity: Children aged ≤18 years with oropharyngeal dysphagia, including those with neurologic impairments (mean/median age below 7 years).
study_duration: Follow-up was less than 6 months in most studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a hybrid training system (HTS) providing antagonist muscle electrical stimulation was more effective than sensory TENS in altering pain sensitivity in women with obesity and frequent knee symptoms during walking exercise.
results_summary: The HTS group showed statistically significant improvement in local pain sensitivity at the knee compared to the control group, but no significant difference was found for remote pain sensitivity at the wrist. The HTS group also demonstrated a trend toward reduced knee pain, though this did not reach statistical significance.
population_specificity: Women aged 40-70 with obesity and daily knee symptoms (N=28).
effective_dosage: Biweekly 30-minute walking sessions with HTS or sensory TENS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the latest evidence for behavioral swallowing therapies, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation, for Parkinson's disease-related dysphagia to inform evidence-based treatment decisions.
results_summary: Behavioral therapies, including those enhancing airway function and intensive targeted swallowing treatment, improved swallowing function in PD, but the chin-down strategy showed no significant effect. EMST detraining effects suggested a need for maintenance training.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) experiencing dysphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in preventing deep venous thrombosis (DVT) of the lower extremities after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in baseline characteristics between the experimental (NMES) and control groups. Outcomes such as VAS score, blood D-dimer levels, knee circumference, and DVT screening results were compared pre- and post-operation.
population_specificity: 187 males and 91 females who underwent anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.
study_duration: Intervention was administered from pre-operation to the fourth day post-operation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding NMES to TKA rehabilitation improves quadriceps strength recovery compared to standardized rehabilitation and to identify common NMES pulse settings and their effectiveness.
results_summary: NMES was found to be effective for quadriceps strength recovery, particularly early after TKA, with similar long-term effects to traditional strength training. Short duration and low-intensity NMES had limited effects, and there was heterogeneity in NMES methodologies and pulse settings.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (heterogeneity in NMES settings noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improves lower limb muscle strength after living donor liver transplant (LDLT).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in muscle strength, functional capacity, activities of daily living, or hospital stay between the NMES and control groups after 4 weeks. However, the authors suggested further research with novel NMES devices or other body areas might yield different results.
population_specificity: Adult patients who underwent living donor liver transplant (LDLT) at a university hospital.
effective_dosage: NMES applied to quadriceps muscles starting 1 day post-LDLT (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation as a rehabilitation procedure for managing sarcopenic dysphagia.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation is one of several possible rehabilitation procedures for sarcopenic dysphagia, but its specific efficacy remains unclear due to the narrative review's broad scope and lack of detailed findings.
population_specificity: Patients with sarcopenic dysphagia (dysphagia with generalized sarcopenia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) is metabolically safe when administered within the first 72 hours of septic shock diagnosis or later.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in metabolic variables (e.g., Oxygen Consumption) during NMES compared to control protocols, indicating NMES is metabolically safe in both acute and late phases of septic shock. However, metabolic demand was higher in the acute phase.
population_specificity: Patients with acute septic shock (within 72 hours of diagnosis) and late-phase sepsis/septic shock (after 72 hours).
study_duration: Intervention and control protocols were compared with a wash-out period of 4 to 6 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improves postoperative quadriceps muscle strength, functional status, and quality of life in patients undergoing fast-track total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: Preoperative NMES showed significant improvement in patient-reported function (KOOS-function in daily living and WOMAC total score) but had non-significant trends for quadriceps strength, pain, symptoms, performance-based activity, and quality of life. No significant postoperative benefits were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for fast-track total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of inspiratory plus expiratory neuromuscular electrical stimulation in subjects with severe COPD.
results_summary: The study found that inspiratory plus expiratory neuromuscular electrical stimulation significantly improved functional exercise capacity (6MWD) in severe COPD patients compared to diaphragm pacing, with no serious adverse events reported. Secondary outcomes showed no significant differences between groups, except for improvements in FEV1 and FEV1/FVC in GOLD-4 COPD subjects.
population_specificity: Stable COPD patients with severe respiratory impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of conventional pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) versus biofeedback-mediated PFMT combined with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for improving pelvic organ prolapse (POP) symptoms in postpartum women.
results_summary: The study found that biofeedback-mediated PFMT combined with NMES was evaluated for its long-term efficacy in improving POP-Q staging and quality of life, with results pending at 36 months post-intervention. The trial design suggests potential benefits, but conclusive outcomes are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Postpartum women with symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse (POP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of foot orthoses (FOs) for treating paediatric flat feet, including interventions like neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for NMES, as the focus was primarily on comparing foot orthoses (CFOs, PFOs) versus shoes and each other. NMES was listed as one of the interventions but not analyzed separately.
population_specificity: Children aged 11 months to 19 years with flexible flat feet, including asymptomatic, juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), symptomatic, and developmental co-ordination disorder (DCD) presentations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of a single NMES session on foot force production, foot dome stability, and dynamic postural control in individuals with static foot pronation.
results_summary: A single NMES session significantly improved foot function and dynamic postural control compared to sham stimulation, with 78% of NMES participants responding positively to at least two outcomes. The relative risk of being a responder was 3.6 times higher in the NMES group.
population_specificity: 46 participants (23 males, 23 females) with static foot pronation (Foot Posture Index score ≥ 6).
effective_dosage: 15-minute NMES session on the dominant foot.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and other activity-based physical therapies in influencing bone metabolism and increasing bone mineral density (BMD) in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found sparse and inconsistent evidence supporting NMES and other physical rehabilitation regimens in improving bone metabolism or BMD at fracture-prone sites in individuals with severe SCI. The review highlights the need for optimized ABPT approaches for bone recovery post-SCI.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI), particularly those with severe paralysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of NMES with pulse widths of 300 μs and 200 μs for treating overactive bladder (OAB) in elderly women.
results_summary: NMES significantly reduced OAB symptom scores in both groups, with greater improvement observed in the 300 μs group. Both pulse widths increased myoelectric potential in Type I and Type II muscle fibers, but the 300 μs group showed significantly higher improvements.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal elderly women without pelvic organ prolapse (POP).
effective_dosage: Group A: 300 μs pulse width; Group B: 200 μs pulse width.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of foot orthoses (FOs) for treating paediatric flat feet, including interventions like neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for NMES, as the focus was primarily on comparing foot orthoses (CFOs, PFOs) versus shoes and each other. NMES was listed as one of the interventions but not analyzed separately.
population_specificity: Children aged 11 months to 19 years with flexible flat feet, including asymptomatic, juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), symptomatic, and developmental co-ordination disorder (DCD) presentations.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of NMES combined with rTMS on upper limb motor dysfunction in stroke patients with hemiplegia.
results_summary: NMES combined with rTMS significantly improved upper extremity motor function and daily life activities in stroke patients with hemiplegia, outperforming NMES or rTMS alone. The combined treatment group showed notably higher scores in FMA-UE, MBI, and MAS compared to other groups.
population_specificity: 240 stroke patients with hemiplegia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on functional capacity in patients during the immediate postoperative period of cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the distance walked (primary outcome) or other functional measures between the intervention and control groups, concluding that neuromuscular electrical stimulation provided no benefit in this context.
population_specificity: Patients in the immediate postoperative period of cardiac surgery at a specialist hospital in Brazil.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, twice a day, for up to 10 sessions.

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation (CCFES) versus neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on motor recovery of the upper limb in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: Both CCFES and NMES improved upper limb motor function, but CCFES did not show a superior treatment effect compared to NMES. CCFES significantly enhanced the sEMG response of the paretic extensor carpi radialis but did not reduce antagonist cocontraction.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients within six months poststroke.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) improves functional strength and endurance in addition to muscle hypertrophy.
results_summary: NMES treatment led to statistically significant improvements in abdominal and quadriceps strength and endurance, with nonsignificant changes in waist and quadriceps circumference. High subject satisfaction was reported for strength improvements.
population_specificity: 26 subjects randomized into 3 groups (2 treatment, 1 control).
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 4 and 8 weeks posttreatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardiovascular safety, applicability, and effects of blood flow restriction combined with passive mobilization (BFRp) or neuromuscular electrical stimulation (BFRpE) on neuromuscular adaptations, physical function, and quality of life in comatose ICU patients.
results_summary: The study protocol was designed to evaluate the effects of BFRp and BFRpE, but results were not yet available as the abstract describes a prospective trial. The discussion suggests the data will inform future trials on preventing muscle atrophy and improving physical function and quality of life.
population_specificity: Comatose patients in intensive care units (ICUs).
effective_dosage: Training protocol applied to both legs alternately, twice a day with a 4-hour interval.
study_duration: Until coma awakening, death, or ICU discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the differential effectiveness of intradialytic neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and protein supplementation on muscle strength, mass, physical function, and quality of life in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that intradialytic NMES improved muscular strength, mass, functional capacity, and quality of life in hemodialysis patients, with potential synergistic effects when combined with protein supplementation.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: NMES delivered to four areas of the bilateral vastus medialis and vastus lateralis using a 4-channel NMES instrument; 25 g of protein supplements provided per dialysis session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of intravaginal NMES combined with PFMT on urinary loss and quality of life in women with SUI, as well as its cost-effectiveness and cost-utility.
results_summary: The study protocol suggests that NMES combined with PFMT may be an effective treatment option for SUI, but specific results are not detailed in the abstract. The hypothesis is that concurrent NMES and PFMT will optimize treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Women (biological) aged ≥18 years with stress urinary incontinence (≥1 episode/week), excluding those with vaginal/urinary infections, virginity, pregnancy/puerperium, or neurological diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically map rehabilitative interventions, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (PES), for dysphagia in patients with moderate-to-severe acquired brain injury (ABI).
results_summary: The study found positive tendencies towards beneficial effects for PES (a form of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation) in retraining swallowing function in ABI patients, though it emphasized the need for standardized protocols and outcome measures.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe ABI (predominantly stroke) and dysphagia in the acute and subacute phase (within 6 months of injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of short-term intradialytic NMES on inflammation and quality of life in chronic kidney disease patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in cytokine concentrations (hs-CRP, IL-6, IL-10, TNFα) or quality of life domains after NMES intervention. Muscle strength and mass also showed no differences between groups.
population_specificity: Adult hemodialysis patients with chronic kidney disease (control group: n=11, NMES group: n=10).
effective_dosage: NMES applied bilaterally at thigh and calves for 40 minutes during each hemodialysis session (three times a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on functional capacity and quality of life in cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: NMES improved knee extensor strength but had no significant effects on 6-minute walking distance, walking speed, grip strength, or quality of life. The evidence was limited by low to moderate study quality.
population_specificity: Cardiac surgery patients (400 participants across six studies).

study_goal: To determine the effects of NMES/FES training on body composition parameters (e.g., muscle cross-sectional area, lean mass, fat mass) in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: NMES/FES training increased muscle cross-sectional area by an average of 26% and showed modest changes in lean mass and fat mass. Higher weekly training volumes correlated with greater muscle hypertrophy.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Stimulation parameters ranged from 200-1000 μs pulse duration, 2-60 Hz frequency, and 10-200 mA amplitude.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of non-invasive neurostimulation therapies, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (sNMES), in improving swallowing function in dysphagia patients after stroke.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that non-invasive neurostimulation therapies, including sNMES, significantly improved swallowing function in stroke patients compared to controls, with rTMS showing the best performance in subgroup analyses. The effect was more pronounced in acute-phase patients and those with brainstem injuries.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with dysphagia (914 participants across 27 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of NMES on muscle torque and sports performance in long-distance recreational runners.
results_summary: The NMES group showed significant improvements in peak isometric, concentric, and eccentric quadriceps muscle torque, as well as enhanced ventilatory anaerobic thresholds and oxygen cost of transport compared to controls.
population_specificity: Long-distance recreational runners (30 volunteers, 15 in each group).
effective_dosage: 1 kHz, modulated in 2 ms bursts, 50 Hz modulated burst frequency, 10% duty cycle, 15 min per session (18 contractions per session), 3 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular pathways and potential interventions, including physical rehabilitation and drug combinations, to mitigate muscle atrophy following severe spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study identified rapid muscle atrophy post-SCI driven by specific signaling cascades and highlighted the limited effectiveness of traditional anabolic agents, suggesting combined physical rehabilitation and targeted drug therapies as a more promising approach.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) training and a progressive exercise program (PEP) versus standard primary care management (PCM) in improving physical performance, pain, and torso strength in service members with subacute low back pain.
results_summary: NMES showed greater improvement than PCM in physical performance (sit-ups and push-ups) and similar improvements in torso strength, with no group differences in pain levels. NMES muscle stimulation amount directly correlated with improvement, unlike PEP exercise hours.
population_specificity: Active duty military personnel (n=128) with subacute low back pain at Fort Campbell, Kentucky.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate NMES as an adjunctive pre- and post-operative treatment for rectal cancer patients undergoing radical pelvic surgery to assess its efficacy in improving key health outcomes.
results_summary: The study is a phase II randomized controlled trial evaluating NMES's impact on skeletal muscle attenuation (a marker of myosteatosis), sarcopenia, quality of life, inflammatory status, and cancer-specific outcomes, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Rectal cancer patients undergoing radical pelvic surgery (pelvic exenteration).
study_duration: 2 weeks pre-operatively and 8 weeks post-operatively (total 10 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of laparoscopic implantation of neuroprosthesis (LION) with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in improving walking ability and other outcomes in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in walking ability (WISCI II scale) for the NMES group, while the LION group showed improvement. No significant changes were observed in secondary outcome measures for either group.
population_specificity: Individuals with traumatic SCI (AIS grade A), aged 18-55, neurological level Th4-L1, and time-since-injury >1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding NMES to exercise therapy during the first 14 days post-stroke improves gait recovery compared to exercise therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvement in walking distance (6MWT) or any secondary outcomes when NMES was added to exercise therapy. The NMES group showed a non-significant 28.3m improvement in 6MWT at 90 days, but this was not clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: First-ever acute ischemic stroke patients (ages 40-85) with leg paresis.
